question: What are the IATA and ICAO codes assigned to the Baltic capital's main aviation hub, which was the base of operations for an airline that folded in 2015?
llm_answer: The Baltic capital’s main aviation hub is Vilnius Čiurlionis International Airport, whose IATA code is VNO and ICAO code is EYVI.

context.text: aircraft movements per day. On the outside, it is decorated with sculptures of soldiers, workers and aviators, while inside walls and ceilings feature wreaths, bay leaves and stars, and until the early 1990s, the Soviet hammer and sickle, typical decor for Soviet public buildings of early post-war years.  A new departure terminal, connected with the old building, was built in 1993. Since then, the old building has been used as the arrival terminal only. In November 2007, the new 1,000 m 2 (10,764 sq ft) terminal building was opened for operations which improved the capacity and facilities of the airport and complies with the requirements of the Schengen agreement .  The passenger throughput of the terminal increased, passenger service quality was improved and more stringent aviation security measures were implemented. The new area of the renovated passenger terminal now reaches 3,462 m 2 (37,265 sq ft). It is equipped with 6 passenger boarding bridges, modern passenger check-in equipment, new travel value and duty-free shops were opened as well as business lounge and VIP Lounge. New departure terminal Construction of a new departure terminal at Vilnius Airport started in January 2023. After the completion of this 14,400 m 2 (155,000 sq ft) terminal, the total area of Vilnius Airport passenger terminals will increase by one third, and passenger throughput will double – from 1,200 passengers per hour to 2,400. Together with the construction of the new terminal, a redevelopment of road infrastructure is planned, including upgrades of engineering networks and a new transport scheme. The terminal was opened on 4 February 2025. with projected cost of 50.2 million euros. Airlines and destinations Passenger The following airlines operate regular scheduled and charter flights to and from Vilnius: Cargo Statistics Interior of the historic entrance hall Departures area Control tower Annual traffic Busiest routes Most frequent routes Ground transportation Vilnius airport railway station The bus connecting the airport with Vilnius Train Direct train services between Vilnius Airport Railway Station (referred to as "Oro uostas" in the schedules) and the central station of Vilnius were started in October 2008. Distance from the Airport to the Vilnius Central Railway Station (LTG Link) is 4.3 kilometres (2.7 mi), the journey takes 8 minutes. Bus The direct intercity express services operate from the Airport to Klaipėda, Palanga, Minsk and Daugavpils. Also, the Latvian company Flybus.lv operates service from Vilnius airport to Riga (via Panevėžys and Bauska). Public transportation City's public buses operate from the airport. Tickets can be bought from: Trafi, M.Ticket. Also, the company Toks transports passengers from the bus station to Vilnius airport

Vilnius Čiurlionis International Airport ( IATA : VNO , ICAO : EYVI ) ( Lithuanian : Tarptautinis Vilniaus Čiurlionio oro uostas ) is the airport of Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania . It is located 5.9 km (3.7 mi) south of the city center. It is the largest of the three commercial airports in Lithuania by passenger traffic, with one runway and 5 million passengers a year. Vilnius International Airport serves as a base for airBaltic , Ryanair , and Wizz Air . The airport is managed by Joint Stock Company Lithuanian Airports under the Ministry of Transport and Communications . It is the 96th busiest airport in Europe . In honor of Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis , the airport was renamed to Vilnius Čiurlionis International Airport ( Lithuanian : Tarptautinis Vilniaus Čiurlionio oro uostas ) from 1 January 2025, to 31 December 2029. History Early years The opening of the Warsaw–Vilnius–Riga–Tallinn airline on 17 August 1932 The airport began operations in Second Polish Republic on 17 August 1932 as Wilno –Porubanek, Porubanek was the name of the neighbouring village which today is part of the Kirtimai district of Vilnius. Before World War II , it operated the then-domestic route between Wilno (Vilnius) and Warsaw as well as international route to Riga. Since 15 April 1939, it inaugurated a new route to Kaunas . The airport was used as a military airfield during the war. The airport resumed its activity as a civil airport as of 17 July 1944. Recent developments Lithuanian Airlines (branded later as FlyLAL ) was established as the Lithuanian flag carrier following independence in 1991 and inherited the Vilnius-based Aeroflot fleet of Tupolev Tu-134 , Yakovlev Yak-40 , Yak-42 and Antonov An-24 , An-26 aircraft, but rapidly replaced these Soviet-era aircraft types with modern Boeing 737 and Boeing 757 jets and Saab 340 , Saab 2000 turboprops. Operations were suspended effective 17 January 2009 as a result of growing financial difficulties. With the collapse of flyLAL, the airport lost its scheduled services to Amsterdam, Budapest, Istanbul, Madrid and Tbilisi . flyLAL used to operate to Dublin, Frankfurt, London, Milan and Paris in competition with Aer Lingus , airBaltic and Lufthansa .  AirBaltic , the national airline of Latvia and under Scandinavian Airlines part-ownership, opened up a

Lea County Regional Airport ( IATA : HOB , ICAO : KHOB ) (Lea County-Hobbs Airport) is four miles (6.4 km) west of Hobbs , in Lea County , New Mexico , United States . The airport covers 898 acres (363 ha) and has three runways. It is an FAA certified commercial airport served by United Airlines ' affiliate with daily regional flights. Lea County Regional Airport is the largest of the three airports owned and operated by Lea County Government. Lea County also owns and operates two general aviation airports in Lovington and Jal, New Mexico . Facilities The airport covers 898 acres (363 ha) and has three asphalt runways: 3/21 – 7,398 × 150 ft (2,255 × 46 m) 12/30 – 6,002 × 150 ft (1,829 × 46 m) 17/35 – 4,998 × 100 ft (1,523 × 30 m) In the year ending January 31, 2023 the airport had 15,445 aircraft operations, average 42 per day: 83% general aviation , 14% air taxi , 3% military, and <1% airline. 57 aircraft at the time were based at this airport: 51 single-engine, 3 multi-engine, 2 jet, and 1 helicopter. The airport has one terminal for all arrivals and departures, and two FBOs , Tailwind Aviation and Christian Aero. The data below lists annual total aircraft operations from 2009 to 2013 from the FAA's air traffic activity system. The percent changes indicate an average of −13.93% in aircraft operations per year over these five years. Airlines and destinations Statistics History Me-Tex Airport opened on July 23, 1937, where the Hobbs golf course is now, next to Lea County Regional Airport. The Me-Tex Supply Company had leased land from the state and built oiled runways and a hangar at Me-Tex. In 1940, the city of Hobbs passed a bond issue to purchase some adjoining acreage, with the intent of bringing airline service and airmail delivery. Federal grants helped pay for paved runways and taxiways and a terminal building for Hobbs Municipal Airport, which opened during World War II. Me-Tex Airport closed in 1946–47. Ownership of the airport was transferred from the city of Hobbs to Lea County on November 19, 1945 The terminal building was expanded in the late 2000s and another significant expansion occurred in the late 2010s. Historical airline service The first air mail arrived in Hobbs via Continental Airlines in May 1940, and started passenger flights that year to Albuquerque , El Paso , San Antonio , and Tulsa , each making several stops en route. Service was started using

2025 [update] , Iran Airtour operates the following aircraft: Accidents and incidents Since 1993, Iran AirTour has had three fatal aircraft accidents. On 8 February 1993, a Tupolev Tu-154 , Iran Airtour Flight 962 , shortly after departure from Tehran International Airport , crashed into a Sukhoi Su-24 of the Iranian Air Force which was landing. In this accident, all 133 people – both pilots of the Su-24 and Tu-154, all 12 crew members, and 119 passengers on board – died. The main cause of this accident was the Sukhoi Su-24 pilot's error. On 12 February 2002, a Tupolev Tu-154 , Iran Airtour Flight 956 , flying from Tehran to Khorramabad , crashed into the Sefid Kooh mountains during heavy rain, snow and dense fog. All 12 crew members and 107 passengers died. On 1 September 2006, a Tupolev Tu-154 , Iran Airtour Flight 945 , flying from Bandar Abbas to Mashhad , with 11 crew and 137 passengers on board, burst into flames upon landing at Mashhad International Airport , 28 out of the 148 passengers and crew died. See also List of airlines of Iran References External links Media related to Iran Airtour at Wikimedia Commons Official website Portals : Iran Companies Aviation

Idaho Falls Regional Airport ( IATA : IDA , ICAO : KIDA , FAA LID : IDA ) is two miles north-northwest of downtown Idaho Falls , Idaho , United States. It is locally known as Fanning Field . It is the second-busiest airport in Idaho after Boise Airport . The National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2011–2015 categorized it as a primary commercial service facility. Federal Aviation Administration records say the airport had 148,584 passenger boardings (enplanements) in calendar year 2008, 138,957 in 2009 and 144,365 in 2010. In 2024, 610,641 passengers boarded flights at IDA, which was an 11.9% increase from 2023. This was also a 73.2% increase from 2019. Facilities Idaho Falls Regional Airport covers 866 acres (350 ha ) at an elevation of 4,744 feet (1,446 m). It has two asphalt runways: 3/21 is 9,002 by 150 feet (2,744 x 46 m) and 17/35 is 3,964 by 75 feet (1,208 x 23 m). In the year ending December 31, 2016, the airport had 33,152 aircraft operations, average 91 per day: 65% general aviation , 31% air taxi , 3% airline and <1% military. 171 aircraft were then based at this airport: 128 single-engine, 29 multi-engine, 6 jet, 5 helicopter , and 3 glider. History A historic portion on the east side of the airport was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997. The listing included two contributing buildings and a contributing structure on 4 acres (1.6 ha): an aircraft hangar , an administrator or caretaker's cabin, and a beacon tower, as well as a surrounding landscaped area. It "represents" the original site of operations for the Idaho Falls Airport. The hangar was still in use in 1996. Terminal The airport terminal has seen many expansions and a partial re-build throughout the years. The current terminal was built in 1959. The first expansion happening in 1982, which consisted of the old boarding area being torn down and retrofitted with jetways to accommodate smaller commercial aircraft that started coming in the mid-2000s. The previous terminal was designed with jetways for older generation Boeing 737, which stopped arriving in Idaho Falls after Delta Air Lines pulled out of mainline service to the airport in 1998. In 2014, an expansion project was completed that moved TSA screening of baggage out of view of passengers and allowed airlines to again check baggage from ticket counters. In 2019, the airport saw a need for a bigger baggage claim area.

Iran Airtour is a privately owned Iranian airline that was launched in 1973. Its main base is Mashhad Airport . History Foundation and early years Iran Airtour is one of Iran's private airlines, established in 1973 by Iran Air with the aim of launching tours to the cities of Iran and different countries. In 1982, Iran Airtour started scheduled domestic tours from all over Iran to Mashhad . Two years later, the airline started to develop foreign tours to China , UAE , India , Singapore and Malaysia .  Iran Airtours flight activity as an independent airline started in 1992 in Mashhad, which became the operations center of the airline. A direct air link from Mashhad to the centers of 13 provinces ensued. Iran Airtour was also responsible for operating flights from different cities to Mecca for pilgrimage , as well as regional flights with 19 aircraft to Damascus , Stockholm , Moscow , and Ashgabat .  Development since 2010 Until 2010, Iran Airtour was one of the state-owned airline companies in Iran, but subsequently, in accordance with Article 44 of the Constitutional law, ownership was assigned to Hesayar Co., a subsidiary of the Iranian Ministry of Defence . Because four of five consecutive payment checks from Hesayar Co. bounced for insufficient funds, the original assignment was canceled. After another auction in 2016, the airline was conceded to the private sector . In October 2021, Iran Airtour got permission to fly in the European airspace, making it the second Iranian airline to be able to do so.  Iran Airtour is also one of the companies that has a license for aviation training in Iran (ATO) from the National Aviation Organization. Iran Airtour is a member of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and holds the IATA Operational Safety Audit (IOSA), audited by IATA-approved auditors. Iran Airtour Airlines consists of more than 1300 specialized and skilled personnel in different parts.  On 17 January 2025, it was reported that Iran Airtour will launch non-stop flights between Tehran and Paris commencing 31 January 2025. The route will be serviced two times weekly with its Airbus A300-600 aircraft. In addition, new routes to Germany , Spain and Italy are in the pipeline and will be launched in March 2025. Destinations Iran Airtour's primary base is Mashhad Airport . As of April 2023, Iran Airtour operates scheduled services to the following destinations. Fleet Airbus A300-600 . McDonnell Douglas MD-82 . As of August 2025 [update] , Iran Airtour operates the following aircraft: Accidents and incidents Since 1993, Iran AirTour has had three fatal aircraft accidents. On 8 February 1993, a Tupolev Tu-154 , Iran Airtour Flight 962 , shortly

Boise Airport ( IATA : BOI , ICAO : KBOI , FAA LID : BOI ) ( Boise Air Terminal or Gowen Field ) is a joint civil-military airport in the western United States in Idaho , three miles (5 km) south of downtown Boise in Ada County . The airport is operated by the city of Boise Department of Aviation, overseen by an airport commission. Boise Airport is the busiest airport in the state with more than 5.2 million passengers serviced in 2025. Boise Airport services roughly ten times as many passengers as the next busiest airport at Idaho Falls . In 2020 it serviced more passenger flights than all other Idaho airports combined. Boise is a landing rights airfield requiring international general aviation flights to receive permission from a Customs and Border Protection officer before landing. In addition to being a commercial and general aviation airport, Boise also functions concurrently as a USAF military facility as used by the 124th Fighter Wing (124 FW) of the Idaho Air National Guard on the Gowen Field Air National Guard Base portion of the airport. The 124 FW operates the A-10 Thunderbolt II aircraft. The National Interagency Fire Center is based in the city of Boise and the Boise Airport is used for logistical support. The United States Forest Service (USFS) also uses Boise Airport as a base for aerial firefighting air tankers during the wildfire season. Boise Airport enplaned 2,248,435 passengers in 2022, an increase of 24% vs. 2021 when 1,806,838 passengers were enplaned. Terminals and development Boise Airport currently has one terminal with two concourses and servicing ten airlines. The terminal is a three-story building containing four baggage carousels, rental car counters on the ground floor, all of the ticketing counters, a consolidated security checkpoint including TSA PreCheck and CLEAR Security, offices and fast food outlets. The two concourses have a combined 24 gates with 13 total jet bridges. Concourse B has 13 gates and 11 jet bridges (with one jet bridge serving each of B21 a/b and B22 a/b). Airline gate assignments are broken down as follows: B10, B11, B21 a/b (United), B15, B17 (Southwest), B14, B16, B19 (Common Use), B18 (American), B20, B22 a/b (Delta). The Common use gates are used as follows: B14 (Delta), B16 (Allegiant, Frontier, Southwest), B19 (American, Spirit, Sun Country). Concourse C serves Alaska Airlines and has 11 gates; however, only gates C8a and C12 are equipped with jet bridges, with the rest having covered walkways. In 2016, Boise Airport released a new master plan outlining their short, medium, and long-term plans. Each of these terms would mark different stages

Air Florida DC-9 parked at Tallahassee Airport Tallahassee International Airport ( IATA : TLH , ICAO : KTLH , FAA LID : TLH ) is a public airport located about 5 miles (8 km) southwest of downtown Tallahassee in Leon County , Florida , United States. Owned and operated by the City of Tallahassee, it serves as the primary airport for Florida's capital city and the surrounding Big Bend region. Despite its designation as an " international airport ", TLH currently does not offer scheduled international passenger flights. The international status was granted in 2015 following the installation of a federal customs and border protection facility, enabling it to handle international cargo and charter flights. As of 2024, the airport provides commercial passenger service through several major airlines, including American Airlines , Delta Air Lines , and Silver Airways , offering nonstop flights to key hubs such as Atlanta , Charlotte , Dallas/Fort Worth , and Miami . With annual passenger traffic averaging between 850,000 and 900,000, Tallahassee International Airport ranks as one of the smaller commercial airports in Florida, yet remains a crucial transportation hub for the northern part of the state. TLH covers approximately 2,485 acres (1,006 hectares) and features two asphalt runways: Runway 9/27, measuring 8,000 feet (2,438 meters), and Runway 18/36, measuring 7,000 feet (2,134 meters). The airport accommodates commercial flights, cargo operations, general aviation, and military use. It also supports flight training programs affiliated with local educational institutions, including Tallahassee Community College and Florida State University . The airport also serves a vital role in regional emergency management, often functioning as a staging area for hurricane relief and other disaster response efforts due to its inland location and proximity to the Gulf Coast . Economically, TLH supports thousands of jobs in the region and contributes millions of dollars annually to the local economy through passenger travel, cargo operations, and associated businesses. History Mayor Joe Cordell and the City Commission at the new Tallahassee Municipal Airport on March 28, 1961 The airport began as Tallahassee Municipal Airport with a ceremony on April 23, 1961. The United States flag was presented to the City of Tallahassee by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker , World War I fighter ace and Chairman of the Board of Eastern Airlines . U.S. Army aircraft from Fort Rucker , Alabama, performed an aerial demonstration. Tallahassee Municipal replaced the city's first airport, Dale Mabry Field , which closed that year. Eastern Airlines opened the airport by ferrying city, state, and chamber of commerce officials. Aboard the flight were Tallahassee Mayor Joe Cordell, State Comptroller Ray Green, Tallahassee City Commissioners Davis Atkinson, George Taff, Hugh Williams, Tallahassee City Manager Arvah Hopkins,

Eastern Airways was a British regional airline headquartered at Humberside Airport near the village of Kirmington , North Lincolnshire , England. The airline operated domestic, international and private charter flights. Around 1,300,000 passengers flew with the airline per rolling year including on services for KLM Cityhopper, charter operations, and government subsidised public service obligation (PSO) services which would otherwise be commercially unfeasible. The airline had its own hubs in Aberdeen and Humberside . Air Kilroe held a United Kingdom Civil Aviation Authority Type A Operating Licence. It was permitted to carry passengers, cargo and mail on aircraft with 20 or more seats and was IOSA approved. History Early years Co-founded by Bryan Huxford and Richard Lake, the airline started operations in December 1997 with a scheduled route between Humberside and Aberdeen with a leased Swearingen Metro , following KLM UK's withdrawal from the route. In February 1999, it purchased Manchester based Air Kilroe , thereby acquiring an air operator's certificate and a fleet of two BAe Jetstream 32 aircraft. In 2002, the first BAe Jetstream 41 entered the Eastern fleet, the aircraft type which formed the majority of the fleet up until the airline ceased operations. 12 aircraft and their associated routes were transferred from British Airways CitiExpress on 30 March 2003. An Embraer 145 and 135 were also wet-leased from City Airline in 2003, which were then replaced with Saab 2000 aircraft, which peaked at 8 being operated by 2013 including acquisitions from Crossair and other European carriers. In 2006, Eastern Airways wet-leased a Dornier 328 from Cirrus Airlines for six months to operate a Newcastle to London City service before switching this onto the BAe Jetstream 41. Eastern Airways also purchased a Jetstream 41 training simulator . As part of One NorthEast 's "Passionate People Passionate Places" campaign for North East England , Eastern Airways had a Jetstream 41 painted in promotional colours. It also featured in the 2007 Sunderland International Airshow . A Saab 2000 was also painted in a promotional 'Aberdeen City and Shire' colour scheme. The airline shut down its hub at the Isle of Man in August 2009, discontinuing routes to Birmingham and Newcastle from the airport. 2010s In July 2010, the airline took delivery of an Embraer 135 with 37 seats and signed a lease on a second, thus adding jet aircraft to their fleet for the first time since the acquisition to replace their previously operated Embraer ERJ aircraft. They were to be used mainly on charter services to central and Eastern Europe; however, they also offered increased flexibility on the airline's scheduled flights. In July 2010, the airline named one of their BAe Jetstream 41 aircraft

in July 2017. Accidents and incidents 9 October 2013 – The passenger of Cessna 172 G-BCYR made a successful emergency landing at Humberside following the death of its pilot in flight. The passenger had no flying experience and was talked down by flying instructors. He had been on a local flight from Sandtoft Airfield , Lincolnshire when the pilot died. The incident formed the basis of a documentary broadcast in the United Kingdom by Channel 4 on 27 March 2014. References External links Wikimedia Commons has media related to Humberside Airport . Official website Portals : United Kingdom England Aviation

communities.summary:
**Title**: Humberside Airport Operations  

**Summary**:  
Humberside Airport, located in North Lincolnshire, England, transitioned from a WWII RAF base to a regional airport serving passenger, cargo, helicopter, and general-aviation traffic. Scheduled passenger numbers peaked near 500,000 in the mid-2000s but fell to ~200,000 by 2016, with several short-lived airline services. The airport thrives as a North Sea offshore-energy hub, recording over 5,000 helicopter movements in 2016 and hosting major operators such as Bristow, CHC, and UNI-FLY. Infrastructure includes a 02/20 runway, a dedicated FBO opened by Weston Aviation, flying clubs, maintenance academies, on-site hotels, and ground-transport links via bus and nearby Barnetby railway station. Ownership shifted from Manchester Airports Group to the Eastern Group; Bristow Helicopters now holds the majority stake.  

**Keywords**:  
Humberside Airport, offshore helicopter hub, North Sea energy, passenger decline, aviation infrastructure

**Title**: Vilnius Čiurlionis International Airport

**Summary**: Vilnius Čiurlionis International Airport (VNO) is Lithuania’s largest commercial airport, handling ~5 million passengers annually and serving as a base for airBaltic, Ryanair, and Wizz Air. Opened in 1932, it has evolved from a modest inter-war airfield to a modern hub with a new 14,400 m² terminal opened in 2025, doubling passenger capacity. The airport has weathered airline collapses, a 35-day closure for runway reconstruction in 2017, and temporary shutdowns due to smuggling balloons, while continuously upgrading infrastructure and expanding route networks across Europe.

**Keywords**: Vilnius airport, VNO, Lithuanian aviation, airBaltic hub, terminal expansion

**Title**: Air Lituanica History

**Summary**: Air Lituanica was a short-lived Lithuanian flag-carrier founded in 2013 to restore scheduled service after FlyLAL and Star1 ceased flying. Headquartered in Vilnius and backed by the city municipality, it launched with an Embraer E-170 on the Vilnius–Brussels route, later adding Amsterdam, Berlin, Prague and Munich. After its lessor Estonian Air repossessed the E-170 in late 2013, the airline shrank, operated only an E-175, and suspended operations on 22 May 2015 before filing for bankruptcy.

**Keywords**: Air Lituanica, Lithuanian airline, Vilnius, Embraer E-170/E-175, bankruptcy

**Title**: Tallahassee International Airport History

**Summary**:  
Tallahassee International Airport (TLH) opened in 1961 as Tallahassee Municipal Airport, replacing Dale Mabry Field, and has since evolved into a key regional hub. Early milestones include hosting Freedom Rider protests in 1961 and expanding infrastructure in the 1980s with a new runway and terminal. Renamed Tallahassee International in 2015 after adding U.S. Customs facilities, it now supports cargo, general aviation, military operations, and commercial flights via American, Delta, and Silver Airways. The airport spans 2,485 acres with two runways and handles ~900k passengers annually, while also serving emergency management and educational flight programs.

**Keywords**:  
Tallahassee airport history, runway expansion, Freedom Rider protests, international designation, regional aviation hub

**Title**: Boise Airport History & Incidents

**Summary**:  
Boise Airport, tracing its roots to 1926 as Booth Field, evolved into a major regional hub with United Airlines operating continuously for a century. The airport’s history includes WWII training operations, jet service introduction in the 1960s, and major terminal renovations in the 2000s. Future expansion plans include a new Concourse A and three parking garages. Alongside its growth, the airport has experienced several fatal aviation accidents and a recent hangar collapse, highlighting ongoing safety challenges.

**Keywords**:  
Boise Airport, aviation history, airport expansion, aviation accidents, United Airlines

**Title**: Boise Airport Operations & Facilities

**Summary**:  
Boise Airport (BOI) is a dual-use civil-military airfield anchored by the 124th Fighter Wing (Idaho Air National Guard) flying A-10s after divesting its C-130 fleet in 2009. The airport’s 5,000-acre campus features two 9,700-ft+ parallel runways, a 295-ft control tower/TRACON (Big Sky Approach), and a 378,000-ft² post-9/11 terminal that earned national design acclaim. Annual traffic nears 140,000 operations (46% GA, 39% airline) with 2.7–4 M passengers; Horizon/Alaska Airlines dominate commercial service. Facilities include a donated FedEx 727 trainer for first responders, on-base FBOs, and historic HAER-documented Gowen Field structures.

**Keywords**:  
Boise Airport, 124th Fighter Wing, Gowen Field, Big Sky Approach, A-10 Thunderbolt

**Title**: Vilnius Airport Operations & Incidents

**Summary**: Vilnius International Airport serves as Lithuania’s primary aviation hub, offering public bus links via Trafi/M.Ticket and microbus shuttles by Toks, plus aviation services from BGS and Litcargus. The airport has experienced several high-profile incidents: a 2007 SAS Dash-8 gear-collapse, the 2021 Ryanair Flight 4978 forced diversion to Minsk, and a fatal 2024 Swiftair cargo crash. Additional recent events include runway/taxiway excursions by Brussels Airlines, Avion Express, and LOT, prompting temporary closures.

**Keywords**: Vilnius Airport, aviation incidents, Ryanair diversion, SAS Dash-8, Lithuania transport

**Title**: 1993 Tehran Mid-Air Collision

**Summary**:  
On 8 February 1993, Iran Airtour Flight 962, a Tupolev Tu-154 with 131 people on board, collided mid-air with an Iranian Air Force Sukhoi Su-24 near Tehran, killing everyone on both aircraft. The Tu-154 was climbing to 6,000 ft after takeoff while five Su-24s, preparing for a ceremonial flypast, were descending to land under visual flight rules. An air-traffic controller cleared the airliner to climb without informing either crew of the converging traffic; one Su-24 drifted off assigned altitude and turned into the Tupolev’s path. Both aircraft crashed into an army depot at Shahr-e Qods. Investigators blamed the controller for permitting simultaneous climb/descent and the military pilots for altitude deviation.

**Keywords**: Tehran mid-air collision, Iran Airtour Flight 962, Sukhoi Su-24, air-traffic control error, 1993 aviation disaster

**Title**: Iran Airtour Airline Profile

**Summary**: Iran Airtour, founded in 1973 as a subsidiary of Iran Air and privatized in 2016, is a Mashhad-based Iranian carrier operating domestic and international scheduled and charter flights. The airline’s fleet comprises Airbus A300-600 and McDonnell Douglas MD-82 aircraft, and it recently gained access to European airspace, launching Tehran–Paris service in early 2025. Between 1993 and 2006 the company suffered three fatal Tu-154 accidents that claimed a total of 268 lives, but it has since pursued safety certifications including IATA’s IOSA. With over 1,300 employees, Iran Airtour also holds an aviation training license and plans new European routes to Germany, Spain, and Italy.

**Keywords**: Iran Airtour, Iranian airline, fatal accidents, European flights, IOSA certification

**Title**: George AFB F-4 Training Operations

**Summary**: George Air Force Base, California, served as a premier USAF training hub from the 1950s through the Cold War, specializing in F-4 Phantom II and Wild Weasel (F-105F/G, F-4G) crew instruction. After the 479th Tactical Fighter Wing transitioned from F-104s to F-4s in the mid-1960s, the 35th Tactical Fighter Wing took over in 1971, operating multiple training squadrons that qualified U.S. and allied pilots in F-4C/D/E variants and advanced radar-suppression tactics. The base closed in 1993 under BRAC, later becoming the Southern California Logistics Airport.

**Keywords**: George AFB, F-4 Phantom, Wild Weasel, 35th TFW, pilot training

**Title**: George Air Force Base Operations

**Summary**: George Air Force Base served as a key USAF installation from WWII through the Cold War, evolving from Victorville Army Airfield’s training hub for pilots, bombardiers, and glider crews to a front-line base for air-defense and tactical-fighter units. Successive wings—the 1st Fighter-Interceptor Wing, 479th Tactical Fighter Wing, and several Fighter-Interceptor Squadrons—operated F-86, F-100, F-102, F-104, and F-106 aircraft, pioneering new jets and deploying worldwide, including MiGCAP over Vietnam and air-defense during the Berlin and Cuban crises. After closure under 1988 BRAC, the site transitioned to civilian logistics, energy, and training uses.

**Keywords**: George AFB, 479th TFW, F-104/F-106, Cold War, pilot training

**Title**: Logan Thunder WNBL Team

**Summary**: The Logan Thunder was an Australian professional women’s basketball team based in Logan, Queensland, competing in the Women’s National Basketball League (WNBL). Established in 2008 to replace the Christchurch Sirens, they marked the return of WNBL representation to South East Queensland after a decade. Financial difficulties led to their withdrawal from the 2014/15 season, after which the team folded.

**Keywords**: Logan Thunder, WNBL, women’s basketball, Queensland, team history

**Title**: Chicago Tigers 1920 Season

**Summary**:  
The Chicago Tigers played their sole season in 1920, the inaugural year of what became the NFL, and are recognized as the league’s first franchise to fold. Competing at Wrigley Field (then Cubs Park), they posted a 2-5-1 record against APFA opponents despite never formally joining the league. Key figures included quarterback Johnny Barrett and ends Jack Meagher and Oscar Knop, with a passing attack noted as their offensive strength. A high-profile 10-0 loss to George Halas’ Decatur Staleys and a later 6-3 defeat to the Racine Cardinals fueled a legend that the Tigers agreed to disband if they lost the city’s “winner-take-all” showdown, though evidence for this pact is weak. The team folded after 1920, succeeded in local lore by the Hammond Pros and ultimately the Staleys, who became the Chicago Bears.

**Keywords**:  
Chicago Tigers, 1920 APFA season, Wrigley Field, George Halas, NFL franchise folding

**Title**: Lea County Regional Airport History

**Summary**: Lea County Regional Airport (HOB) west of Hobbs, New Mexico, has evolved from a 1937 airstrip into a 898-acre commercial airport with three asphalt runways. After Continental Airlines introduced airmail and passenger service in 1940, a succession of carriers—Trans-Texas/Texas International, Mesa, New Mexico Airlines, and ultimately United Express—linked Hobbs to hubs such as Albuquerque, Dallas, Houston, and Denver. Aircraft upgraded from Lockheed Electras to regional jets, while terminal expansions in the late 2000s and 2010s accommodated growing traffic. Ownership transferred from the city to Lea County in 1945, and today the airport handles roughly 42 daily operations, 83% general aviation.

**Keywords**: airline service evolution, Hobbs New Mexico, airport expansion, United Express, Lea County

**Title**: Alberta’s Unwritten Constitution  

**Summary**:  
Alberta lacks a single written constitution; instead, its governing rules are an uncodified collection of statutes, court rulings, proclamations, and conventions modeled on the U.K. system. Within Canada’s federal structure, the province may legislate only on matters assigned under s. 92 of the Constitution Act, 1867 and must respect the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The federal Alberta Act (1905) established the province’s basic framework, yet Alberta can alter its internal arrangements—such as switching electoral systems—without Ottawa’s approval. In 1990 Alberta used the federal amending formula to constitutionalize protections for its Métis settlements, its sole exercise of that option to date.  

**Keywords**:  
Alberta constitution, unwritten constitution, federal-provincial division of powers, Métis settlements, Alberta Act 1905

**Title**: 2009 Iranian AWACS Crash

**Summary**: On 22 September 2009, Iran’s sole airborne early-warning aircraft, an Il-76MD Adnan 2 (“Simorgh”), crashed during a military-parade flyby over Tehran, killing all seven crew members. Conflicting accounts blame either a mid-air collision with an F-5E/Saeqeh fighter or the detachment of its radome while the crew attempted an emergency landing after an engine fire. The loss eliminated Iran’s only operational AWACS platform, significantly degrading its aerial surveillance capability.

**Keywords**: Il-76MD Adnan 2, Iranian AWACS, 2009 Tehran crash, mid-air collision, radome failure

**Title**: Eastern Airways Operations History

**Summary**:  
Eastern Airways, a British regional airline based at Humberside Airport, operated from 1997 until entering administration in November 2025. The airline evolved from a small operator using Jetstream aircraft to a multifaceted carrier providing scheduled, charter, PSO-subsidised lifeline routes, and ACMI flying for KLM Cityhopper. Key developments included franchise agreements with Flybe, expansion into oil-and-gas shuttles, acquisition by Bristow Group and later repurchase by founder Richard Lake, and fleet upgrades to ATR 72-600s and Embraer 190s. After Flybe’s 2020 collapse, Eastern attempted strategic growth at Southampton, Cardiff, and Gibraltar, but most new routes were short-lived. Long-term Public Service Obligation contracts—notably Newquay–Gatwick and Aberdeen–Wick—underpinned regional connectivity until administration ended all flights and terminated the remaining PSO services.

**Keywords**:  
regional airline, Public Service Obligation, Flybe franchise, KLM Cityhopper, administration

**Title**: Savannah/Hilton Head Airport History & Expansion

**Summary**: Savannah/Hilton Head International Airport began as a 1929 municipal field, evolved through military and civilian phases, and now spans 3,650 acres with two long concrete runways. Its most unusual feature is Runway 10, whose asphalt contains marked gravestones of the 19th-century Dotson family, left in place because next-of-kin could not be found. Major 1994 and 2007 expansions created a 15-gate terminal, parking garage, and new infrastructure for $68.5 million, with further TSA lanes and four more gates under construction through 2025. The airport hosts the 165th Airlift Wing of the Georgia Air National Guard and has earned repeated #1 U.S. airport rankings for passenger satisfaction.

**Keywords**: runway graves, airport expansion, Savannah history, military base, passenger awards

**Title**: 1955 Cincinnati Mid-Air Collision

**Summary**: On January 12, 1955, Trans World Airlines Flight 694 collided mid-air with a private Douglas DC-3 shortly after takeoff from Boone County Airport, killing all aboard both aircraft. The DC-3 had entered controlled airspace without clearance or radio contact, and its left wing was struck by the climbing Martin 2-0-2, severing the latter’s right wing and causing both planes to crash two miles apart. Investigators blamed the DC-3’s unauthorized entry into the traffic zone, while TWA later filed a $2 million lawsuit against the Castleton Corporation that owned the private aircraft.

**Keywords**: mid-air collision, 1955 Cincinnati, TWA Flight 694, airspace violation, aviation safety

**Title**: Idaho Falls Regional Airport Airline History

**Summary**: Idaho Falls Regional Airport (IDA) has experienced shifting airline service since National Parks Airways first arrived in 1934–35. Major carriers such as Western/Delta, American, Horizon, United Express, Allegiant, Northwest/Delta, Frontier, and SeaPort have periodically added and removed routes to hubs like Salt Lake City, Denver, Seattle, Las Vegas, Dallas/Fort Worth, Minneapolis, Oakland, and Chicago, often via code-shares or regional affiliates. Aircraft evolved from early DC-3s and Fairchild F-27s through Boeing 727/737, MD-80, DC-9, Dash 8, CRJ-200, EMB-120, Q400, and E-175 jets, while terminal expansions in 1982, 1998, 2014, 2019, and 2020 adapted to changing traffic. After Horizon’s final 2010 exit, Delta Connection (SkyWest) and United Express emerged as primary carriers, supplemented by Allegiant and seasonal Delta mainline A220s during Jackson Hole’s 2022 runway work, pushing enplanements to 610,641 in 2024.

**Keywords**: Idaho Falls Regional Airport, airline service history, Horizon Air, Delta Connection, terminal expansions

**Title**: Adelaide Lightning History  

**Summary**:  
The Adelaide Lightning, formed in 1993, are a cornerstone of Australia’s Women’s National Basketball League (WNBL), based in Adelaide, South Australia. The club dominated the mid-1990s, winning three consecutive titles (1994-96) and a fourth in 1998, with Olympic star Rachael Sporn as captain. After private ownership changes and a 2008 championship, the team faced financial instability, multiple licence transfers, and a 2025 expulsion threat. A last-minute South Australian Government rescue package in May 2025 secured the franchise, funding a league-run team and relocating home games to the State Basketball Centre in Wayville for the 2025-26 season.  

**Keywords**:  
WNBL, Rachael Sporn, Adelaide Lightning, ownership changes, State Basketball Centre

**Title**: Southwest Florida International Airport Evolution

**Summary**: Southwest Florida International Airport (RSW) opened in 1983 to replace overcrowded Page Field, starting with a 14-gate terminal and an 8,400-ft runway. Rapid passenger growth—surpassing 3 million by 1988 and 11 million by 2025—triggered successive expansions: a midfield terminal in 2005, a 12,000-ft runway, a Federal Inspection facility, and multiple concourses. International service began with 1984 Toronto flights, followed by European routes to Germany cultivated through local German-American ties. Recent projects include a $1.1-billion terminal expansion, a consolidated security checkpoint, a new air-traffic-control tower, and planned Concourse E and commercial Skyplex development.

**Keywords**: RSW expansion, international routes, terminal development, passenger growth, Lee County aviation

**Title**: Canadian Federalism & Quebec Unity

**Summary**:  
Canada’s federal system balances federal and provincial powers, with Ottawa’s broad spending authority—though not explicitly constitutional—allowing conditional transfers like the Canada Health Act to shape provincial policy. Quebec’s distinct civil-law identity and repeated constitutional clashes drive national-unity debates, including two sovereignty referendums (1980, 1995) and failed accords. Federal politics operates through Westminster-style, first-past-the-post elections where party leaders control disciplined caucuses, producing majority or minority governments that must maintain House confidence. Representation guarantees—three Supreme Court justices from Quebec and bilingual leadership expectations—underscore the province’s central role in federal stability.

**Keywords**:  
federal-provincial relations, Quebec sovereignty, spending power, national unity, parliamentary system

**Title**: Canadian Parliamentary Democracy & Monarchy

**Summary**:  
Canada operates as a federal parliamentary democracy within a constitutional monarchy, where the monarch (currently Charles III) serves as ceremonial head of state while executive power rests with the prime minister and Cabinet, accountable to the elected House of Commons. The Westminster-derived system emphasizes egalitarianism, multiculturalism, and social justice, with a centrist “brokerage” party landscape historically dominated by the Liberals and Conservatives. Constitutional autonomy from Britain was completed in 1982, yet many Canadians display limited civic awareness of the Crown’s role. Strong party discipline and confidence conventions concentrate influence in the executive, leaving backbench MPs to exert sway mainly through parliamentary committees.

**Keywords**:  
constitutional monarchy, parliamentary democracy, federal system, brokerage politics, civic literacy
